content: The number of Medal of Honor recipients from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan can be counted on one hand. Each of the five acted spontaneously and heroically to save the lives of comrades. Each exemplified the medal’s criteria of “gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of one’s own life above and beyond the call of duty.” And each was killed in action or died from wounds received in action. From World War I through Vietnam, the rate of Medal of Honor recipients per 100,000 service members stayed between 2.3 (Korea) and 2.9 (World War II). But since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, only five Medals of Honor have been awarded, a rate of 0.1 per 100,000 — one in a million. A similar disparity occurs on the second tier of valor awards: Distinguished Service Cross, Navy Cross and Air Force Cross. Throughout the 20th century, the rate of service cross recipients per 100,000 troops ranged from a low of 19 in Korea to a high of 167 in World War I. But for the post-9/11 wars, it’s only one per 100,000. Why? More here: "http://marinetimes.com/news/2009/03/military_medal_of_honor_032509w/" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: Two possible reasons come to my mind: It appears that "posthumous" has become an "unofficial official" criteria for being awarded the MOH. Why that is, I don't know, but I seem to recall a couple of cases of individuals having their MOH nominations downgraded apparently because they lived through the event in question. OTOH, the opportunities for posthumous award have also declined because of our superb battlefield medical care. Second, given the nature of the conflicts in Iraq and A-stan, the general lack of prolonged, close combat against a conventional enemy that normally produces the vast majority of MOH nominations, is probably a factor also. Just my .01 worth.

content: One possible reason for the apparent disparity in numbers is that Iraq, and to a slightly lesser degree, Afghanistan, have tended to be very small unit operations ... squad, team, section, etc. That pushes award preparation to a lower level ... and makes validation more difficult. It would be interesting to see an analysis similar to that in the opening comment that compares nominations for the award rather than the numbers of awards actually given. My guess would be that percentage wise, far fewer nominations have been initiated for Iraq/Afghanistan than were initiated for other wars.

My guess would be that percentage wise, far fewer nominations have been initiated for Iraq/Afghanistan than were initiated for other wars.

content: The number of Medal of Honor recipients from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan can be counted on one hand. Each of the five acted spontaneously and heroically to save the lives of comrades. Each exemplified the medal’s criteria of “gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of one’s own life above and beyond the call of duty.” And each was killed in action or died from wounds received in action. From World War I through Vietnam, the rate of Medal of Honor recipients per 100,000 service members stayed between 2.3 (Korea) and 2.9 (World War II). But since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, only five Medals of Honor have been awarded, a rate of 0.1 per 100,000 — one in a million. A similar disparity occurs on the second tier of valor awards: Distinguished Service Cross, Navy Cross and Air Force Cross. Throughout the 20th century, the rate of service cross recipients per 100,000 troops ranged from a low of 19 in Korea to a high of 167 in World War I. But for the post-9/11 wars, it’s only one per 100,000. Why? More here: "http://marinetimes.com/news/2009/03/military_medal_of_honor_032509w/" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: Why have Iraq and Afghanistan produced only 5 Medal of Honor recipients, none living?

content: One possible reason for the apparent disparity in numbers is that Iraq, and to a slightly lesser degree, Afghanistan, have tended to be very small unit operations ... squad, team, section, etc. That pushes award preparation to a lower level ... and makes validation more difficult. It would be interesting to see an analysis similar to that in the opening comment that compares nominations for the award rather than the numbers of awards actually given. My guess would be that percentage wise, far fewer nominations have been initiated for Iraq/Afghanistan than were initiated for other wars.

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: quote: Originally posted by jack_flats: Apparently Iraq isn't the kind of war that one would associate with a conventional type war where MOH's are more prevalent. Why is that Jack? Anbar, it's not just the MOH. There has been a pattern in recent years to downgrade awards. It's always been done to some extent but it's gotten much worse over the last 10 years. I work with a guy who was hit by a RPG, blew his leg off but he kept returning fire till he ran out of ammo and passed out from blood loss. His suppressive fire while bleeding profusely saved a number of his Joes and he was put in for the Bronze Star. Believe it or not it was downgraded to an AAM with V device. There is no justice.
